movie review: Sure, it has just as much to say about our ignorance toward other cultural rituals (using Swedish folklore), but as a horror film about a failing relationship, Midsommar kind of broke me. (Brendan Cassidy, Rotten Tomatoes)
It relentlessly mocks not only the disgusting prejudice woven into extreme right-wing ideology, but, frankly, the inherently ridiculous nature of many Nazi beliefs. (Calum Cooper, Rotten Tomatoes)

By its final act, when you’ve journeyed through some of its most inspired filmmaking homages, one thing remains clear: “Killers of the Flower Moon” is really a horror film. (Ankit Ojha, Rotten Tomatoes)
t’s so very funny, sweet, and gross in the best ways. There simply isn’t anything else like it. (Zach Youngs, Rotten Tomatoes)
The Green Knight is a cinema experience like few others. (Zach Youngs, Rotten Tomatoes)

movie title: Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind
movie review: ...giving us an ending that is more painfully honest and, as a result, more romantic. (Adam Kempenaar, Rotten Tomatoes)

The quotes and tributes to other films are still present, but here they acquire a new value, especially towards the end, where the cinema becomes a space for revenge... [Full review in Spanish] (Ezequiel Obregón, Rotten Tomatoes)

The airport battle is still one of the best scenes in all of these movies, and the introduction to Holland’s Spider-Man is still such a joy and the best use of his iteration of the character in this series. (Cory Woodroof, Rotten Tomatoes)

It becomes painfully and chillingly obvious how relevant so much of the film’s commentary is, as Lee parallels “old America” to its current state of affairs through appropriate storytelling. (Brittany Patrice Witherspoon, Rotten Tomatoes)
Big is warm-hearted and sweet without ever losing its edge and it engages adult viewers on an intellectual level in a way that few family films do. (Zita Short, Rotten Tomatoes)

'True Lies' is a James Bond fantasy mixed with a genuine love story. It’s a seamless marriage between laugh-out-loud comedy and cartoonish violence. (Preston Barta, Rotten Tomatoes)
It's superbly directed on every level, but the sound design is particularly effective. Typewriter key strikes are mixed with the sound of gunshots: words are weapons. (Wendy Ide, Rotten Tomatoes)
a funny, weird cameo-filled caper that finds value even in vice, and lets wild imagination ultimately win out over drab reality. (Anton Bitel, Rotten Tomatoes)
